author: Mike Sorensen
title: Jimmy Blair, Mike Malaska, Jeff Beaudry, Mark Passey and Keith Hansen inducted into Utah Golf Hall of Fame
text:
Five prominent contributors to golf in Utah were inducted into the Utah Golf Hall of Fame Saturday night.
More Coverage Longtime Bonneville golf pro dies at 96 SALT LAKE CITY — Five prominent contributors to golf in Utah were inducted into the Utah Golf Hall of Fame Saturday night.
Jimmy Blair, Mike Malaska, Jeff Beaudry, Mark Passey and Keith Hansen were honored at a banquet at the Salt Lake Marriott City Center in the eighth induction ceremony since the charter induction in 1994.
Blair won nearly every golf tournament of note in Utah and the Intermountain region, including the Utah State Amateur in 1973 and the Utah Open in 1981. In between he starred for the BYU golf team that finished second in the NCAA tournament. He also won the Idaho Open four times, the Wyoming Open three times, the Colorado Open twice and also played briefly on the PGA Tour. He has also been successful in the golf business, running the Mulligan's Golf Center in Ogden and managing Sun River Golf Club and Bloomington Country Club in St. George.
Malaska grew up in Salt Lake, becoming a top junior golfer and winning the Utah Open at age 20 when he also competed for the Weber State golf team. He was a top professional in Utah for many years, but made his mark as one of the top golf instructors in the world. For the past 15 years, he has ranked among Golf Digest’s “America’s 50 Greatest Teachers” and on Golf Magazine’s list of top 100 teachers for 20 years. He is currently the director of instruction for Nicklaus Academies Worldwide.
Beaudry served as the executive director of the Utah section PGA, where he made an impact with several innovative programs and also helped bring the Ben Hogan Tour (now Web.com Tour) to Utah. He was also instrumental in the partnership of the Special Olympics with Utah golf tournaments and was inducted into the Utah Special Olympics Hall of Fame in 2002. For the past 17 years he has been a key administrator for the PGA of America.
Passey, who was a classmate of Beaudry's at Cyprus High School in the 1960s, began a career in golf administration in the early 1980s on the board of the Logan Golf and Country Club and eventually became one of the top officials at the United States Golf Association. He served as the executive director of the Utah Golf Association from 1985 to 1990 before joining the USGA as one of four regional affairs directors, where he has made a lasting impact on golf in the United States.
Hansen made his mark as a volunteer and became one of the top rules officials in the United States. He has officiated more than 75 USGA national championships, along with dozens of NCAA and other national events as well as hundreds of events in Utah. He also was a two-time president of the Utah Golf Association and has conducted numerous rules seminars in Utah and around the country.
